content.text:
Contents
CHAPTER 1 From Chattel to Intellectual Property: Legal Foundations of African American Cultural Critique
CHAPTER 2 Critical Race Theory, Signifyin’, and Cultural Ownership
CHAPTER 3 Defining Hip-Hop Aesthetics
CHAPTER 4 Claiming Ownership in the Post-Civil Rights Era
CHAPTER 5 “Fair Use” and the Circulation of Racialized Texts
CHAPTER 6 “Transformative Uses”: Parody and Memory
CHAPTER 7 From Invisibility to Erasure? The Consequences of Hip-Hop Aesthetics
Notes
Bibliography
Index

document.title: Parodies of Ownership: Hip-Hop Aesthetics and Intellectual Property Law
document.author: Schur, Richard L.
document.publisher: The University of Michigan Press and The University of Michigan Library
